title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act titled "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. It applies to the application of the Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including the Social Security Act, National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, and Occupational Safety and Health Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, and Occupational Safety and Health Act. Congress is also subject to the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies the Freedom of Information Act and Independent Counsel Provisions to Congress, covering Members, employees, elected officers, and Legislative Counsel. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to Members, employees, elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police, and employees of various Congressional instrumentalities. It also includes employees in the district or State office of a Member. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to Members, employees, elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police, and employees of various Congressional instrumentalities. It also includes provisions regarding the district or State office of a Member, political affiliation, place of residence considerations for employment, and exemptions for small businesses. The Small Business Exemption under the Congressional Accountability Act applies to Members based on the number of employees they have, including those working in the District of Columbia. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by actions under this Act can appeal in a Federal district court, with rights and remedies as private persons under relevant laws.
